Main usage of harmonizR

2021-11-17

Source: vignettes/main_usage.Rmd
main_usage.Rmd

Get started

The easiest way to get started with harmonizR is using this vignette as a demo with the current git Rpackage version on GitHub. You must contact Maelstrom to get access to the current version of the package. You will receive an authorization token (in the format “ghp_xxx”) to install the package. You can then install and load harmonizR. The demo files are included with the package.


# To update the R package in your environment you may need to remove it, quit() 
# your session and then re-install the R package

remove.packages("harmonizR")
# terminate R
quit()

devtools::install_github(
  repo = "https://github.com/maelstrom-research/harmonizR",
  auth_token = "ghp_xxx",
  force = TRUE)

library(harmonizR)
harmonizR_help()

Overview

The goal of this vignette is to walk through the process of harmonization using harmonizR, illustrating its main functions, which allow you to:

  • Create an R environment where you can place files in an organized structure
  • Identify the location and content of files in your environment
  • Generate bookdown reports of individual study (input) variables
  • Read and interpret the data processing elements (harmonization rules) and generate harmonized tables
  • Generate bookdown reports of harmonized variables

Demonstration files

To test and use the package, the user can get access to demo files that are downloadable in our Opal demo repo. To download them, make sure you have Opal credentials. Do not hesitate to contact us.


path_from_opal <- paste0("/home/administrator/demo_files")
download_files_from_opal(from = path_from_opal)

Set up your harmonization environment

Create an organized environment to place your files correctly and control versions of your project. Creating a well-organized structure for your project will facilitate the harmonization work and avoid confusion among different versions of project files (e.g., different versions of datasets, data dictionaries, DataSchema, and data processing elements).

# use case 1: create folder without version
project_envir_create(project = "TEST_3")

# use case 2: create folder with a version
project_envir_create(
  project = "TEST_3",
  version = "")

# use case 3: copy a version in the same project
project_envir_create(
  project = "TEST_3",
  version = "version_1" ,
  copy_from = "version_3")

Index the files in your harmonization environment

Create a tibble listing all files in a folder (recursively) with some useful metadata. You can add a filter to your query to exclude folders from indexing. This tibble can also be used to quickly search for the location of a file. Finally, you can read the indexed files and generate objects in the R environment.


# use case 1: create index of files in one folder
index_demo_files <- mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files")

# use case 2: create index of files in one folder excluding data_processing_elements subfolder
index_demo_files <- 
  mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files", pattern = "data_processing_elements", negate = TRUE)

# use case 3: subset index matching a specific file_path query
mlstr_file_index_search(index = index_demo_files, file_path = "study_specific_datasets")

# use case 4: subset index matching a specific file_type query
mlstr_file_index_search(index = index_demo_files, file_name = "study_MELBOURNE_1")

# use case 5: read a file indexed matching a specific file_name query (assign = FALSE)
mlstr_file_index_read(index = index_demo_files, file_name = "study_MELBOURNE_1",assign = FALSE)

# use case 6: read and download files indexed matching a specific file_name query (assign = TRUE)
mlstr_file_index_read(index = index_demo_files ,file_name = "study_MELBOURNE_1",assign = TRUE)

Generate bookdown reports of the individual study variables

Generate QA reports for individual study datasets and help in the assessment of the each individual study

During the assessment of datasets, the user can generate bookdown report (html-based) showing summary statistics for each individual study variable. The statistics generated are determined by the variable format, which can be one of four types: numerical, text, categorical, or dual (numerical variables having also categories). The user can specify a data dictionary, a variable to group statistics by, and the output folder (the current folder by default).


# Create index of files in one folder and read the files
index_demo_files <- mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files")
mlstr_file_index_read(index = index_demo_files, file_name = "study_TOKYO")
mlstr_file_index_read(index = index_demo_files, file_name = "dd_TOKYO")

# use case 1: report of demo dataset TOKYO
generate_individual_study_bookdown_report(
  dataset = study_TOKYO,
  data_dict = dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged,
  to = "demo_files/reports/TOKYO")

# use case 2: report of demo dataset TOKYO, grouped by gndr
generate_individual_study_bookdown_report(
  dataset = study_TOKYO,
  data_dict = dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged,
  to = "demo_files/reports/TOKYO_gndr",group_by = "gndr",out = "ggplot2")

# re-index your files to include new files created
index_demo_files <- mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files")

# read the book down
mlstr_file_index_read(index_demo_files,file_path = "demo_files/reports/TOKYO_gndr/docs/index.html")

Read and run the data processing rules and generate the harmonized dataset

Read and run the data processing elements file line by line or as a whole and harmonize each study specific dataset. Error messages are generated automatically to help identify sources of errors in the data processing elements. Separate scripts for pre-processing datasets before harmonization or post-processing after harmonization can be integrated into the process.


# Read the files
index_demo_files <- mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files")
mlstr_file_index_read(index_demo_files, file_path = "individual_study_datasets")
mlstr_file_index_read(index_demo_files, file_path = "dataschema")
mlstr_file_index_read(index_demo_files, file_path = "data_processing_elements")

# Example 1: all the process of harmonization with data processing elements with errors
mlstr_process_harmonization(
  dataschema = DEMO_dataschema,
  data_proc_elem = `DEMO_data_processing_elements - with error`,
  output_harmo_folder = "demo_files/harmonized_datasets")

# Example 2: use the function check error directly to access the errors. In your
# environment you will find a report attached to harmonization and the date of it.
summarize_harmonization(annotated_data_proc_elem)
rm(annotated_data_proc_elem)

# After correction, re-run all the process of harmonization with the corrected 
# data processing elements.
mlstr_process_harmonization(
  dataschema = DEMO_dataschema,
  data_proc_elem = `DEMO_data_processing_elements - final`,
  name_report = "final_report",
  output_harmo_folder = "demo_files/harmonized_datasets")

Generate bookdown reports of the harmonized variables

Generate QA reports for the harmonized dataset(s) to help in the assessment of harmonization

A bookdown report (html-based) is generated showing summary statistics for each harmonized variable. The statistics generated for each variable are determined by the variable format, which is one of three types: numerical, text, or categorical. Statistics are shown for the pooled harmonized dataset as well as by study. The DataSchema must be specified. The user can specify the output folder (the current folder by default).


# Read the files. Make sure the harmonization has been processed.
index_demo_files <- mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files")
mlstr_file_index_read(index = index_demo_files, file_path = "dataschema")
mlstr_file_index_search(index_demo_files, file_path = "data_processing_elements")
mlstr_file_index_read(index_demo_files, file_path = "harmonized_datasets")

# pool your data in one tibble
harmonized_study_DEMO_table_DEMO <-
  harmonized_study_MELBOURNE_table_MELBOURNE %>%
  bind_rows(harmonized_study_PARIS_table_PARIS) %>%
  bind_rows(harmonized_study_TOKYO_table_TOKYO)

# use case 1: report of harmonized_study_DEMO_table_DEMO.
generate_harmonized_study_bookdown_report(
  harmonized_dataset = harmonized_study_DEMO_table_DEMO,
  dataschema = DEMO_dataschema,
  data_proc_elem = `DEMO_data_processing_elements - work in progress`,
  to = "demo_files/reports/harmonized_DEMO"
  # group_by = "adm_study"
)

# re-index your files to include new files created
index_demo_files <- mlstr_file_index_create(folder = "demo_files")

# read the book down (or open in your browser the file named 'index')
mlstr_file_index_read(index_demo_files,file_path = "demo_files/reports/harmonized_DEMO/docs/index.html")
